content.html:
A new home for code

TTI up until now has been using GitHub to house all of their code, and DeployHQ to deploy it to their servers. Before I was even hired, everyone was on board to move to GitLab. At the very minimum, I enjoy any platform that consolidates CI/CD and code repositories, and GitLab checks so many boxes. Gitea, for example, is just a code repository, so that means you're deploying at LEAST one other application, and probably whatever build agent it requires. GitLab, GitHub, and Azure DevOps at least provide everything under one roof. The fact that Jenkins uses Groovy for their pipelines is a big non-starter for me. And as nice as it is that AWS provides CodeCommit, CodeBuild, and CodeDeploy, they completely disregard UI/UX, which is par for the course for AWS. Imagine telling your developers and their managers that there's no UI for managing merge requests or browsing through code. No thanks. Anyway, I really wanted to deploy GitLab in a container, but there really isn't a lot of support for it in AWS. So after some trial and failure, I resigned to doing it the old fashioned way: EC2. Although the database is on RDS of course. For now, there is an EC2 instance that runs GitLab, and an EC2 instance that runs the GitLab Runner. They are able to communicate over HTTPS. Because we plan on using GitLab Pipelines to deploy infrastructure to CloudFlare

content.html:
Synology and I first crossed paths around 2014 or 2015. Even without having laid eyes on its operating system, I was enamored by its sleek form factor. At that time, I didn't have space for a 42U server rack at home, so it seemed like a flawless solution for data storage. However, fresh into the workforce, newly married, and saving for a house meant a Synology device, along with hard drives, was a distant dream. Thus, my journey around this tech took a detour. I worked my way through tons of random hardware over the next few years. I'll spare the details of the several machines that came and went along with a 42U server rack that I really didn't need. An important thing to note here though, was that in the couple of years leading up to 2018, I went from running several servers and VMs into just needing one server with Docker on it. So it was time to finally pony up the dough and get myself a Synology.

I began with a DS918+, and I couldn't have been more thrilled. If I recall correctly, it was the summer of 2018 when I bought it. I had spent a great deal of time working on my friend Nate's DS1815+, so I knew from the moment it arrived how I wanted to set it up. So I filled it with 4x 2TB WD Reds (CMR), and my journey began. It came loaded with some amazing and useful features: DDNS, VPN server, Docker, and Let's Encrypt, not to mention their stellar suite of apps like Synology Drive, Synology Office, DS Video, DS Photo (now Synology Photos), and many more. DSM developers had truly considered all angles, and I was overjoyed by its ease of use. I was so delighted that I later upgraded to the DS1821+.

But then, our paths began to diverge.

Before upgrading to DS1821+, tension was already mounting between DSM and me. I sought more from my Synology, but it felt like Synology was the one holding me back. At the time, I still needed more storage, and more CPU, so the upgrade to the DS1821+ was necessary. Regardless of which device I was using, DSM is DSM, and the difficulties were the same. The friction started with SSL certificates. If you wished to use a wildcard certificate, you could only do it with Synology's pre-loaded domain, not your custom one. The reasoning behind such a limitation remains elusive to me, and it forced me to find a workaround. Eventually, I landed on the SWAG Docker container from LinuxServer.io. This solution addressed my SSL certificate issue, but it led me to abandon Synology's built-in reverse proxy and pen a myriad of Nginx config files. The built-in reverse proxy lacked support for advanced configurations, but it was fulfilling its role, and the SWAG container demanded more work than I'd hoped for. Thankfully, I later discovered NGINX Proxy Manager, though it brought its own set of complications that I won't get into here.

NGINX Proxy Manager (NPM) works like a dream when it comes to setting up a reverse proxy and an SSL certificate. Yet, Synology reserves ports 80 and 443 for its own purposes. I could've chosen different ports and rerouted all port 80 and 443 requests on my router to the varied ports on the Synology, but I wasn't keen on it. After some fiddling, I shifted Synology's reserved ports from 80 and 443 to 81 and 444, respectively, and NPM started running smoothly. This needs to be done after every Synology update though, so using different ports might have been a better option.

The most significant gripe I had was with Docker. I haven't used Synology's native Docker UI in years because it's not compatible with the features I use. Instead of ignoring those features, it disrupts the UI's functioning. Any modifications made in the UI would fail to preserve the unsupported configuration, thus disrupting my containers. To be precise, if you want anything more than using a bridge or host network, it will cause the UI to malfunction. When I sought to use one container as a VPN gateway for another container or when I wanted to use a Macvlan network to provide a container with its local IP address, it caused the UI to falter. The command-line interface (CLI) was my go-to for most tasks, but it would have been convenient to monitor my containers using the UI. I've been using Portainer for the past few years, and it's been fantastic. It even resolves another significant issue Synology imposed on Docker users: the API. By restricting the API access, Synology diminished Docker's power user experience. However, Portainer has its own API, providing an easy workaround if you use it to manage your containers.

Using a container as a VPN gateway for another container proved more challenging than anticipated. As predicted, this configuration disrupted the Docker UI, and it just didn't function. It failed because the TUN kernel module wasn't loaded. I had to set up a task to load the TUN kernel module on boot. And yes, it must run on boot since every time you restart your Synology, this configuration doesn't persist.

Hopefully, I've painted a clear picture. DSM7.2 was released recently, featuring a new Docker UI called "Container Manager". However, I'll never know if it works, as I use containers as network devices and use Macvlan networks. I don't want to risk damaging my configuration to see if Synology has improved the Docker experience.

While I understand that the things I'm trying to achieve aren't supported, and I'm pushing the device's limits, what baffles me is why Synology would purposely impede my progress. An SSH warning into your Synology is acceptable, but why can't I just have a warning about exposing my Docker API or that Macvlan networks are unsupported? I'm not asking Synology to adjust their platform to cater to these extended use cases, but I think they should take a step back. Even MacOS doesn't obstruct me when I want to do things it dislikes.

In conclusion, the DS1821+ will be my last Synology. As they continue to tighten the screws and veer towards vendor lock-in, it's becoming less appealing. Many of the features and functions I wanted most in DSM appear half-baked and not sturdy enough to prevent me from resorting to third-party applications. The thought of upgrading to a costlier, more powerful device only to face these same issues and then being compelled to buy their expensive proprietary hard drives is unimaginable. It seems like Synology is entering a weird phase where they're pricing themselves out of home labs while simultaneously nerfing their features to a point where they wouldn't work in an enterprise environment. Is small business where they're finding their sweet spot?

I've been in a rush since day one. Born in Pittsburgh, PA, weighing in at over 11 pounds, I started kindergarten when I was 4 and college when I was 16. I completed my coursework in graduate school when I was 22. Needless to say, I was on a mission. Out of school, I got my start in tech working at a casino as a surveillance technician. From there, I worked as a systems engineer for Synectic Systems, the developer of an enterprise video management system. That job landed me in server rooms and data closets all over North America. All the while, I was spending my time playing with this neat tool called Docker. My journey with my home lab began to scale up quickly, and you'll be able to find articles about some of it at this site. The cool part was realizing that all this stuff I was doing with Docker and other automation tools was actually called DevOps, and it was a career path. So now I get paid to have fun.

Aside from my passion for all things DevOps, I earned my bachelor's degree in music technology from Duquesne University. I earned my master's in guitar performance there as well. While I no longer gig or teach music, guitar remains incredibly important in my life, as does music and audio in general. I am very particular about my headphones and speakers, and how they're EQ'd. It is a frustrating hobby.

Undoubtedly the most important part of my life is my family. My wife, Dr. Xinlei Chu, and I met in graduate school, and have been married for almost 10 years at this point. We have a human baby together, and he's two. I frequently have dreams where I help him troubleshoot his Flask API's and CI/CD pipelines. He is much less interested in those things in real life though.

content.html:
I'll just assume you read my previous rant about how Synology is seemingly taking steps that are working against the best interest of themselves and of their customers. Whether you agree with that or not is entirely up to you, but one thing we can all get behind is that their attempts to create a useful, full-featured UI for managing Docker containers continue to fall short. That's ok though, we have Portainer.

In case you aren't aware of it, Portainer is a UI for all of your container management needs. You can create a one-off container, you can manage Docker Compose stacks, you can use webhooks to automate deployments and container updates, and if you have a bunch of machines running Portainer, you can manage a Docker Swarm, or even a Kubernetes Cluster. If I were Synology, I would give up my efforts on trying to build a UI, and I'd strike a deal with Portainer to implement the Community Edition directly into DSM. But hey, Synology has never asked for my advice. No matter, we'll do it without them.

Pre-Requisites

There are a couple of pre-requisites for this that I'm not going to get into. Arguably, this whole article is probably redundant, but installing Docker and enabling SSH via Synology DSM are probably among the first things anyone would do while setting one up. If for some reason, those things aren't done, I am certain that a quick Google search of "Synology enable SSH" and "Synology install docker" will lead you to very clear instructions.

I highly recommend creating a top-level shared folder in DSM specifically for your Docker containers. It is a good place to create shared volumes that store configuration information. In this example, I will assume that you have a shared folder called "docker". Inside that folder, create another directory called "portainer". I recommend not using capitalization, as it does matter when you're navigating the file system via SSH.

Connecting to the Synology

Great, we have our directory. Time to SSH. In your terminal of choice, you can SSH into your Synology via this command:
ssh user@synology_ip_address

If you are using a non-standard port, then you can do this: ssh user@synology_ip_address -p 1234

You'll then be prompted for your password; punch it in and hit enter.

Adding the Portainer configuration

Ok, so now that you're connected to your Synology, we can get Portainer ready to go. Let's navigate to the "portainer" directory that we created earlier. You can do that with this comand:
cd /volume1/docker/portainer

Now it's time to create and edit our container configuration. Let's use Vim! Use this command to create the file and automatically open the editor:
vim docker-compose.yml

Take note that the file must be called docker-compose.yml with no capitalization. After you run that, you should see a relatively blank screen. You can either copy and paste this into it, or you can type i and start writing it in yourself.

version: "3"
services:
  portainer:
    image: portainer/portainer-ce
    container_name: portainer
    command: -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"
      - "9000:9000"
      - "9443:9443"
    volumes:
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
      - /volume1/docker/portainer:/data


Realistically, you can (and perhaps should) keep this configuration as is, but for the sake of understanding, let's take a look at a couple of its components. The command option allows Portainer to interact with the Docker daemon running on the host machine (in this case, the Synology). It accomplishes this by utilizing the -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock argument, which instructs Portainer to connect directly to the Docker daemon. This connection is feasible because we've mapped the Docker socket file in the volumes section. This mapping makes the Docker socket file from the host machine accessible to the Portainer container, enabling direct communication between Portainer and the Docker daemon. Now, if you're not using the /volume1/docker/portainer directory that I suggested earlier, you will need to update this configuration to reflect the directory of your choice. And finally, let's review the port mapping. Port 8000 is used for Portainer's "edge compute" functions, so you most likely can delete that line unless you are deliberately planning to use those features. Of course, you can add it back later if you want. Port 9000 serves up the Portainer UI over HTTP. This is regarded as "legacy" because they encourage you to use an encrypted connection, but if your SSL termination is done via an external proxy, you may want to use this. Port 9443 is where the UI is served via HTTPS. You can use Portainer's UI for your SSL encryption if you choose, but I will continue under the assumption that SSL will be handled through a third party tool like Nginx Proxy Manager or SWAG from Linuxserver.io. Therefore, port 9000 is really the only one we need.

Licensing

This is mostly irrelevant, but Portainer does offer a free enterprise license for users that run 5 or fewer instances of Portainer. You can download the license file from their website and add it to /volume1/docker/portainer. Additionally, if you want to use the enterprise version of Portainer, you should change the image in the above yaml to portainer/portainer-ee.

Starting Portainer

Ok, so your docker-compose.yml file is ready to go. In order to save and exit Vim, hit the escape key, then type :wq. You will now find yourself back in the terminal, and your current directory is the /volume/docker/portainer directory. We're now ready to fire up Portainer. This is the command you will use:

docker-compose up -d


What this command does is quite simple. You are using docker compose to launch the stack using the up argument. The -d flag runs the command in "detached" mode, which prevents the container from receiving input from the terminal and forces the command to run in the background. Once the command is done running, you can navigate to Portainer in your web browser: http://synology_ip_address:9000

Updating

Portainer frequently has updates; some of which bring some pretty cool features. If you ever want to update your Portainer instance to the latest version, all you have to do is SSH into your Synology again, navigate to the Portainer directory again, and run the following two commands:

docker-compose pull
docker-compose up -d --force-recreate


This will pull down the new Docker image, delete your active containers, and create new ones with the latest image. Don't worry, your configuration is still saved in the mapped volume!

Conclusion

DSM7.2 brought us a new container management tool, aptly named "Contanier Manager", but it's too little too late. Using Portainer to interface with your Synology's Docker instance gives you access to the full capabilities of Docker with no limits or compromises while also keeping you from having to remember terminal commands. This is the way.

Great, we have our directory.  Time to SSH.  In your terminal of choice, you can SSH into your Synology via this command:  
`ssh user@synology_ip_address`  

If you are using a non-standard port, then you can do this:
`ssh user@synology_ip_address -p 1234`  

You'll then be prompted for your password; punch it in and hit enter.

### Adding the Portainer configuration
Ok, so now that you're connected to your Synology, we can get Portainer ready to go.  Let's navigate to the "portainer" directory that we created earlier.  You can do that with this comand:  
`cd /volume1/docker/portainer`  
  
Now it's time to create and edit our container configuration.  Let's use Vim!  Use this command to create the file and automatically open the editor:  
`vim docker-compose.yml`
  
Take note that the file must be called `docker-compose.yml` with no capitalization.  After you run that, you should see a relatively blank screen.  You can either copy and paste this into it, or you can type `i` and start writing it in yourself.
```
version: "3"
services:
  portainer:
    image: portainer/portainer-ce
    container_name: portainer
    command: -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock
    restart: always
    ports:
      - "8000:8000"
      - "9000:9000"
      - "9443:9443"
    volumes:
      - /var/run/docker.sock:/var/run/docker.sock
      - /volume1/docker/portainer:/data
```  
Realistically, you can (and perhaps should) keep this configuration as is, but for the sake of understanding, let's take a look at a couple of its components. The command option allows Portainer to interact with the Docker daemon running on the host machine (in this case, the Synology). It accomplishes this by utilizing the -H unix:///var/run/docker.sock argument, which instructs Portainer to connect directly to the Docker daemon. This connection is feasible because we've mapped the Docker socket file in the volumes section. This mapping makes the Docker socket file from the host machine accessible to the Portainer container, enabling direct communication between Portainer and the Docker daemon.  Now, if you're not using the `/volume1/docker/portainer` directory that I suggested earlier, you will need to update this configuration to reflect the directory of your choice.  And finally, let's review the port mapping.  Port 8000 is used for Portainer's "edge compute" functions, so you most likely can delete that line unless you are deliberately planning to use those features.  Of course, you can add it back later if you want.  Port 9000 serves up the Portainer UI over HTTP.  This is regarded as "legacy" because they encourage you to use an encrypted connection, but if your SSL termination is done via an external proxy, you may want to use this.  Port 9443 is where the UI is served via HTTPS.  You can use Portainer's UI for your SSL encryption if you choose, but I will continue under the assumption that SSL will be handled through a third party tool like Nginx Proxy Manager or SWAG from Linuxserver.io.  Therefore, port 9000 is really the only one we need.

### Licensing
This is mostly irrelevant, but Portainer does offer a free enterprise license for users that run 5 or fewer instances of Portainer.  You can download the license file from their website and add it to `/volume1/docker/portainer`.  Additionally, if you want to use the enterprise version of Portainer, you should change the image in the above yaml to `portainer/portainer-ee`.

### Starting Portainer
Ok, so your `docker-compose.yml` file is ready to go.  In order to save and exit Vim, hit the `escape` key, then type `:wq`.  You will now find yourself back in the terminal, and your current directory is the `/volume/docker/portainer` directory.  We're now ready to fire up Portainer.  This is the command you will use:
```
docker-compose up -d
```  
What this command does is quite simple.  You are using docker compose to launch the stack using the `up` argument.  The `-d` flag runs the command in "detached" mode, which prevents the container from receiving input from the terminal and forces the command to run in the background.  Once the command is done running, you can navigate to Portainer in your web browser: `http://synology_ip_address:9000`  

### Updating
Portainer frequently has updates; some of which bring some pretty cool features.  If you ever want to update your Portainer instance to the latest version, all you have to do is SSH into your Synology again, navigate to the Portainer directory again, and run the following two commands:
```
docker-compose pull
docker-compose up -d --force-recreate
```  
This will pull down the new Docker image, delete your active containers, and create new ones with the latest image.  Don't worry, your configuration is still saved in the mapped volume!

### Conclusion
DSM7.2 brought us a new container management tool, aptly named "Contanier Manager", but it's too little too late.  Using Portainer to interface with your Synology's Docker instance gives you access to the full capabilities of Docker with no limits or compromises while also keeping you from having to remember terminal commands.  This is the way.

content.html:
Before I joined TTI, my infrastructure-as-code (IaC) tool of choice was Terraform. Think of it as the brand-name Swiss Army knife for managing your infrastructure; in theory, it has all the tools you need, and everyone knows it. For exactly those reasons, I ignored my friend’s suggestions to explore Pulumi for quite some time. I planned to go full-speed ahead with Terraform at TTI. After all, any new DevOps engineer joining our team would likely be well-acquainted with Terraform.

However, wrestling with Terraform's HashiCorp Configuration Language (HCL) syntax can feel like learning a new language every time you use it after a break. It's one of those things that's easy to forget if you're not working with it regularly. On the other hand, I know Python and (some) JavaScript. So, in the spirit of experimenting, I decided to give Pulumi a shot. Lo and behold, I was pleasantly surprised.

I took up the task to spin up GitLab in EC2 using Pulumi and Javascript. The process was so seamless, so effortless, that I bid Terraform a swift goodbye. The ease and familiarity of JavaScript meant that not only could I cruise through configurations, but my developer colleagues could as well. And trust me, that's a real lifesaver when you're not around to troubleshoot.

To illustrate the difference, consider this: creating a new CNAME record in Cloudflare using JavaScript with Pulumi is as straightforward as:

if (stack.startsWith('qa-')) {
    const record = new cloudflare.Record(`${commitHash}-record`, {
        zoneId: "",
        name: `${commitHash}.qa.${domain}`,
        value: pagesProject.url,
        type: "CNAME",
        ttl: 1,
    });
}

Compare this to the same operation in HCL with Terraform:

resource "cloudflare_record" "record" {
  count        = var.stack_name != null && var.stack_name != "" && substr(var.stack_name, 0, 3) == "qa-" ? 1 : 0
  zone_id      = var.zone_id
  name         = "${var.commit_hash}.qa.${var.domain}"
  value        = var.pages_project_url
  type         = "CNAME"
  ttl          = 1
  proxied      = false
}

With Terraform, you're left forced to use a lengthy ternary operator comprised of substring functions and explicit index ranges. Not to mention that there's no easy way to handle conditional logic as Terraform doesn’t natively support the if-else construct, so ternary operations are as good as it gets.

But perhaps the most significant hurdles lie in Terraform's approach to environment management. While workspaces let you manage multiple environments, they all share the same configuration. That's akin to having a single blueprint for all the rooms in a building - it works until you need to customize a room. By leveraging a full-featured programming language like JavaScript, Pulumi enables me to use a single script to accommodate various environments.

These challenges that Terraform faces paint a vivid picture of why Pulumi, with its robust programming language support and more advanced state management, won my vote. As I architect some epic automation, dynamically creating production-like environments for QA, I cannot imagine grappling with these Terraform hurdles.

But that's a story for another day. So, stay tuned as we venture further into the dynamic infrastructure automation.

content.html:
It's been just shy of a month since I embarked on my journey at TTI. As the company's first DevOps engineer, I've been tasked with a colossal project – transitioning everything from Rackspace to AWS. This move isn't just a simple hop from one platform to another, but a shift in mindset, moving from the traditional VMs to more efficient containers.

It's a big job, no doubt. But, it's the kind of challenge that gets you excited to wake up in the morning. It's like when you're waiting for the delivery of a much-anticipated tech gadget. The anticipation, the possibilities - it's all part of the game.

To keep the team in the loop with the project, I've been posting regular updates on our Slack workspace. Think of it as my tech vlog of sorts, where I share what's going on behind the scenes. It's a good way to keep everyone informed, and hopefully, answer a few questions before they're even asked. Plus, it allows the team to jump in if they see something they'd like to discuss further. It's a bit like live-streaming my thought process - unfiltered, raw, and real.

What I didn't expect, though, is how much writing all this down actually helped me. It's turned out to be a sort of "rubber duck debugging" exercise. If you're not familiar with the concept, it's where you explain your code line by line to a rubber duck (or any inanimate object, really) in an effort to spot any errors or ways to improve it. Except, in my case, I'm not talking to a rubber duck, but to a whole team of fellow tech enthusiasts.

After some time, I realized that I was sitting on a ton of material that could be valuable to others outside of our Slack workspace. All these notes, all this "rubber duck debugging" could be lost in the infinite scroll of Slack messages. That's when it hit me. Why not share my experiences, my day-to-day encounters, and discoveries, with a broader audience?

So, here we are. If you've ever wondered what it's like to be a DevOps engineer, or are just interested in tech and how it shapes our world, stick around. I'll be pulling back the curtain on my work, sharing the highs and lows, the challenges, and the triumphs, in a way that I hope will be interesting and insightful. Let's jump in, shall we?
